channel.title: MDMA Addiction?
channel.description:
Well as many of you know I'm a fairly avid experimenter of different drugs mainly for educational purposes and curiosity. My first experience with molly was about a year ago and since then I would probably say its grown from recreational use to abuse. I'm aware that MDMA as a single compound is not physically addictive however also understand that I've never tested any of the powder that I get so I have no idea what kind of stimulants my powder was cut with. Taking into consideration that the vast majority of substances used to cut MDMA are amphetamine or methamphetamine it would explain the addiction sensations I'm currently having. Please note that I have never purchased or taken ecstasy in a pressed pill or capsule form and have always purchased powder and parachuted it.
I will refer to a "dose" of MDMA being anywhere between 100mg and 300mg depending on the apparent "potency".
Recently my MDMA use has gone from once every couple months, to once every couple weeks, to once every weekend and now my use is becoming apparent during the work week as well. I dose without even thinking about it and afterwards I ask myself why I just did that but then it is too late.
I also wake up after a night of MDMA use and all I want is more, and I crave it.
I would rather not discontinue my use of MDMA however I do not want to let it get a hold of my life in a negative way which it seems it already has. Any help or suggestions is very welcome. I am mature enough to dump this stuff cold turkey if need be, but I have looking for any helpful insight from you guys.

item.description:

I would love to say to you, that if you just hammer it for the next while, you’ll just get bored of it in a few months.

But then I remember the many friends in highschool that went e-tard.

I know exactly what you mean by making this topic though. You want to quit, but really you don’t =/ Easiest way is to have the proper motivation to quit. Even though you feel its negative effects and spend money on it, and you’re unsure of your ability to quit, you still dont have that raw motivation to quit which makes it so much easier. That is why I said to hammer it until you get bored and the high sucks and the comedown even worse. But not everyone works the same, because a lot of people I know didn’t get bored.

If you can’t seem to get in the proper mind-state for quitting, then your only other option is to man up and take the initiative.

item.description:
@Greeny wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:15, topic:384571”][quote author=Greeny link=topic=480334.msg3516925#msg3516925 date=1299071421]

Just looking from the outside here, it sounds like you need to stop, and right now. Anytime you get into any type of addiction like that, which starts to control your life, you need to stop. Whether it be an addiction to drugs, video games, whatever. It’s only going to get worse if you don’t.

Yes and no, addiction is human nature, which is why it is so easy to get addicted to gambling, gaming, almost anything (psychologically). I think it’s down to the individual to decide if its ruining their lives, if it is then they should stop. Physical addiction is completely different, and I would indeed avoid that. Which is why I don’t drink alcohol or caffeine.
[/quote]

I wasn’t accusing him of being addicted, I think he did that himself (read: topic title). He also said he found himself doing it all the time even when he didn’t realize it/want to, so it seems to be at least on the road to ruining his life, which is why I advised him to quit.[/quote]

That’s fair enough and I don’t disagree with that, I was just pointing out that many people are addicted to things and it doesn’t always have a negative impact on their life. Coffee drinkers for instance.

I’m not disagreeing with anything that’s really being said in this thread, I just wanted it to be understood that addiction is more common than people would like to agree, and the vast majority of the population probably have a drug habit without even realising. As you said, in those moments when something does seem to be controlling your life, it’s probably time to take a break. However if you are a functional addict (especially if you are more functional with your addiction) then you should take time and decide what is best for you, not just do what society would tell you to do (which is almost always quit).

item.title: MDMA Addiction?
item.dc:creator: @Greeny Greeny
item.description:
@Greeny wrote:

Physical addiction is a state of dependence from constant daily use of a substance. Your body gets used to the working normally with the drug, and when you discontinue its use you feel negative withdrawal symptoms, directly caused by the lack of intake of that substance. Obvious examples include; caffeine, nicotine and alcohol. I could go more scientific, but I think I’ve explained sufficiently for you to understand what I mean here.

Psychological addiction is completely different and a much more ambiguous area to discuss as it varies with person to person. Gambling is not physically addictive, despite the fact you put no substance into your body people still get very addicted. It can be stopped without withdrawal symptoms (so there is no physical dependence/addiction).

Physical addiction is physical and psychological (because the physical withdrawal symptoms give you psychological cravings). Psychological addiction however can be completely in your own head without the need for any physical chemical to be entered into your body for it to start (I presume because you produce your own chemicals naturally doing something you enjoy).

item.title: MDMA Addiction?
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

Greeny:

there is nothing physically addictive about gaming or gambling. It’s human nature

What part of human nature is there that isn’t physical?

I got a little tangential, really my point was that it doesn’t matter whether its physical or mental.

But since you brought it up, how are they different? Do you believe in a soul? What component of “human nature” isn’t physical?

Also, people have a tendency to bring their own definitions of physical addiction to the table when it comes to things like this - and it’s completely impossible to separate different peoples definitions without getting into semantics.

For example, MDMA is not generally considered a physical addiction - yet it is documented (iirc) that habitual use downregulates 5HT-2 receptors (which is what Ollie meant by “drains serotonin” I think, despite them being different). If it downregulates physical receptors, and due to that you desire more/experience negative effects after stopping use, how is that not “physical”? Yet most people (experts included) don’t consider it so.

It’s such a mess to keep using the two terms when all we care about is behavior, imo.

EDIT:

ncbi.nlm.nih.gov

Repeated administration of MDMA causes transient down-regulation of serotonin 5-HT2 receptors.

U Scheffel, JR Lever, M Stathis and GA Ricaurte, Neuropharmacology, Sep 1992

The present study examined short- and long-term effects of MDMA (3,4-methylene-dioxymethamphetamine) on serotonin (5-HT2 and 5-HT1c) receptors in the brain of the rat. N1-Methyl-2-[125I]lysergic acid diethylamide ([125I]MIL) was used to label these receptors in vitro and in vivo. The usefulness of [125I]MIL for in vivo detection of changes in 5-HT2 receptors was confirmed in preliminary experiments in which rats were treated chronically with mianserin (5 mg/kg, once daily for 10 days). Decreases in specific in vivo binding of [125I]MIL, after treatment with mianserin were found to be of the same magnitude as those determined by others, using in vitro methods. The MDMA (8 doses; 5-20 mg/kg each) was administered to rats over a period of 4 days. At various times after administration of the last dose of MDMA, the binding of [125I]MIL was measured. Acutely, treatment with MDMA (20 mg/kg) reduced specific in vivo binding of [125I]MIL in all regions of brain studied. For example, in the frontal cortex, specific binding of [125I]MIL was decreased by 80% at 6 hr and by 62% at 24 hr, after cessation of treatment with MDMA. Twenty-one days after administration of MDMA however, the number of binding sites for [125I]MIL was back to control levels. Reductions in in vivo binding of [125I]MIL in frontal cortex were dependent on the dose of MDMA injected and were associated with decreases in the number of binding sites for [125I]MIL (Bmax values) in tissue homogenates of the same area. Autoradiographic studies of MDMA-treated rats confirmed the decreased density of 5-HT2 receptors and also suggested that the 5-HT1c receptor of the choroid plexus was not affected. These results indicate that repeated administration of MDMA caused transient down-regulation of 5-HT2 receptors in the brain of the rat. Further, they demonstrated that [125I]MIL is a suitable radioligand for labeling 5-HT2 receptors, both in vitro and in vivo. Once labeled with an appropriate radionuclide for SPECT (single photon emission computed tomography) or PET (positron emission tomography), MIL should prove useful for monitoring changes in the density of serotonin receptors in the living mammalian brain.

I make no claim to the accuracy of the article, though.

item.title: MDMA Addiction?
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

First, it’s a good idea to drop this idea of “mental” vs “physical” addiction. I think it does more harm than good to think of addiction in this way - after all, addiction is a behavior, it matters little what the cause of the behavior is - and that’s ignoring the fact that after all, at the end of the day, everything is physical… I think there’s a tendency for the layman to use “mental addiction” to mean “not a real addiction” to justify their own behavior.

Secondly, your experience is not unusual. I hear this shit all the time about MDMA not being addictive, and yet everyone who uses it regularly seems to have this period where they hammer it to negative effect - sounds addictive to me!

Take a break. MDMA will still be there when you get back (shit, if you’re finding good stuff now you’ll be able to find it anytime, the country is drier than a bone :/) and the longer it goes on the longer you’ll have the negative effects when parting from it.

I love MDMA, but it’s definitely a drug to keep to irregular use. I haven’t yet met a heavy habitual MDMA user who didn’t regret it a few years down the line, even Ollie will eventually I suspect.

ps That article linked misrepresents Nutt, he has never said that MDMA is safe.
